title: Holy Dial Indicator Jig FlashForge Creator Pro,X and Makerbot Rep2

description.text:
If you have more than one cartesian 3d printer this is a good solution to hold your dial indicator. this is a jig that uses magnets to hold the Harbor Freight Dial Indicator. This holds the indicator far enough above the table so that the spring in the indicator is not interfering with your reading. the magnets are true value -10 Piece Neodymium Super Magnets
MASTER MAGNETICS Model # 07045 Item # 587715 best to slide two in while the part is still hot, the third can be inserted after cool down by opening the hole slightly with a flat screwdriver. use a quarter or butt of a wrench to achieve a press fit. the rear hole is fragile so it is slightly larger. the magnet can be wedged in with a piece of support material or a drop of glue. make sure to clean up any burrs inside the area that comes in contact with the rails. i had trouble getting simplify3d to recognize the holes. with a HUGE hires .stl simplify3d finally printed the holes. Included is a low res version which may work depending upon which slicer you use. this should slide freely while being held downward by the magnets.
the box for the dial indicator can be modded so that this fits too. if you are looking for a similar model that does not require support during printing try this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1377989 cheers,
fdk

FlashForge Creator Pro

No

Yes

.20

20%

2 outline perimeter shells
printed on 95degree bed
235 extrusion temp

author: FelixDkat

description.text:
This is just what the title describes! A mashed-up micro fpv quadcopter using the following parts. I started with a Nano QX and a Hubsan x4 as my first quadcopters. This frame is made to be used with 7mm motors, which I am using with the Nano QX flight controller. I just figure that someone might possibly be in the same situation here with these mixed parts, so I created a new frame from others' original creations. The camera mount is for the Banggood.com 600tvl 170 degree camera. I have Hubsan props in the thumbnail picture to show how they will fit. 
I haven't been able to print it out yet, but I attached a picture of my current FPV setup! LOL

comments.text: I know it's highly unlikely people will read through all the comments before printing...but it pays to print slow on residential quality 3D Printers.  There's a handful of problem areas that will fail 14 hours into a 26 hour print if you don't pay great attention to your settings.  Also the small support at the bottom, center of the spiral tube broke off when inserting the spiral marble riser on both of my completed prints...so that can be a problem area also.  There's a mechanically improved version floating around Thingiverse that I think addresses a few of the issues you'll run into..so you might want to start with that one.  I tried to beef up the areas I was having problems with but opening such a complex model for editing was a no go with all the programs I'm used to working with (Sketchup, etc) so I'll probably try the improved version next.

comments.text:
It is a complete sod to slice. You need at least 8gbs of ram to pull it off under windows 7.
I have 4 lol
managed to finally get it sliced by setting simplify3d visualisation to Basic.
And printing at 0.24 layer height. Any lower layer heights just crashed the system. It will print at 0.3, but figgered as I was printing it very fast, i'd keep the higher resolution.
I was also shooting for the record print speed.
Ran it at 150mm/s, 2 bottom layers, 3 top and 3 perimeters. 15% infill.
Took 8 hours, 49 minutes with flashforge filament and my he3d k200 delta printer :-)
Printed great, had a very few spider strands that a couple minutes with a bendy straw sorted. All four runs work great with 9.5mm ball bearings.
Currently printing the other three parts.
printing them at 0.16 layer height and 100mm/s speed as they need to be a bit more precise to fit well together :-)
Total print time for the entire machine will be 11 hours and 40 minutes. Used just over 300gms of filament :-)
I'll post a made post when it's all together.

It can fit the following:

  • 6 AAA
  • 4 AA

Find and print the AAA lid from Shack90,
Print the attached Stl. (The sketchup was slightly too big, but the stl fits just right)

title: Western Digital My Book Hard drive Stability base

description.text: I just received my new external hard drive when I noticed it was kinda top heavy. So I designed  this base to add some stability to the drive. The base fits between the little rubber feet on the bottom of the drive and gives the hard driver a large surface area. Seems to work pretty well drive is noticeably harder to knock over. I took my measurements for this model from a western digital my book 4 tb model. I would think it should work with the rest of there My book line of external hard drives.

title: Vertical Laptop Stand out of Laser-Cut Acrylic

description.text:
This stand is for storing your laptop vertically on your desk in order to save space while using an external monitor. I made it specifically with the Macbook Air and Pro in mind, but it will work with any laptop up to 0.9" thick! I made this using 4.5mm acrylic sheet on an Epilog Legend 36EXT 75W laser cutter. Before you make it, you will probably have to customize the thicknesses of the slot joints for your material thickness and laser kerf. Units are in inches; scale would be 1:1 in that case. Read all about this build on my blog:
http://mschausprojects.blogspot.com/2016/03/how-to-make-vertical-laptop-stand.html The original drawings are in Autodesk Fusion 360 - you can use/copy/edit with these links:
Side - http://a360.co/1TSF5LB
Center - http://a360.co/1oPPr31 Thanks!
Mike

description.text:
Want a sound when your print is finished? Using RepRapDiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller or other with Adruino Mega 2560 r3 and Ramps 1.4 or likewise? Using CURA or other Slicer with start/end GCode add-on use the following: M300 - Makes a sound
G4 P30000 - Makes a delay of 30000 ms Example of modified end code: M300 - Makes a sound
G4 P30000 - Makes a delay of 30000 ms
M300 - Makes a sound
G4 P30000 - Makes a delay of 30000 ms
M300 - Makes a sound Result = Three large BIP sound with 30 sec interval. UPDATE:
All credit for the update goes to http://www.thingiverse.com/Copyright/about and http://ddrboxman.github.io/RepRapRingtone/:
The M300 can be modified to adjust frequency and delay directly: M300 will make a sound.
with frequency = Snnnn
and the playing time in milliseconds = Pnnnn Example: M300 S7560 P30000 See comment section for further details.

description.text:
future boat
if you download please shoot me a like thanks ( ;

Theoretically this model provides a corner connection for three 16 mm pipes. However, as holes usually shrink for 3D prints, it can be a loose or even tight fit for 15 mm pipes - depending on your printer. So try and measure. If you have pipes with different diameter, you can proportionally scale this model. Important: Don't force the pipes into the horizontal holes, as it may force the layers to separate. (Believe me it does, guess how I know that ;-) )

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes: This model has 1.6 mm walls, so if you have a printer with 0.4 mm nozzle, and you set the shell thickness to 0.8 mm in your slicer, then you will get solid walls around the holes. You can print this model without support, but in that case you will probably have some hanging material within the horizontal holes, where the nozzle printed in the air. That may be okay, depending on your use case. For me it helped to get tight fit for 15 mm pipes.

This is a 3D printed desktop propeller balancer for paramotor propellers. BOM:
-1pcs Printed parts kit.
-4pcs M3x16mm bolt.
-4pcs 623ZZ bearing.
-1pcs 8mm smooth rod lenght 110mm. -Use the bolts for threading the plastic holes and assemble the four bearings on the main parts.
-Superglue both main parts.
-Redrill adaptor with 8mm drill and insert the smooth rod. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inkvURriAjQ

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs. You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com Thank you!

title: BIQ Low cost Peek insulator clamp replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is my Low cost solution to the insulator clamp used on RepRap Extruders  
Here are the drawngs for :  
16mm peek insulator clamp with 6mm extruder barrel.  
10mm peek insulator clamp with 6mm extruder barrel.  
8mm peek insulator clamp with 4mm extruder barrel.  
Last picture shows from left to right a 16mm Peek 10mm Peek 8mm Peek insulators

Cut out the parts using a Laser at FabLab or at home you can print stick and cut these parts as described in my other Things.  
First Check the Peek fits the bigger hole it is a Snug fit if this is ok.  
The 4mm part is glued to the 6mm part with PVA using 4mm screws to hold the two parts together while the glue sets on the 16mm and 10mm versions.  
The 8mm version uses 3mm screws..   
I have been using this clamping system since March 2011 on Huxley Seedling.

description.text: The print should be printed vertically with supports from the build plate only. The arch that is created printed fine for me. I added a support directly into the model where the fan slides into to allow the top part to be printed without needing support. I also added a rib into the model to keep the print upright on the print bed. Both snapped off perfectly for me. Inside the air passage there are many 1 mm wide slots that allow the cavity to be printed without support which wouldn't be able to be removed. This duct does limit your Z axis though. I have not measured by how much but I am still able to print 6 inches in Z easily. X axis is not affected however. The design also divides the air flow inside into fifths with one fifth being directly out of the straight part behind the nozzle and two fifths going to the right and left of the nozzle. No additional hardware is needed, it uses the same screws that hold the stock cooling fan on. The fan just slides into the top of the print. However this duct does limit your Z axis.

comments.text: This is a good one but why not put fan on the side and not from the top. That would clear the top of the case for Z axis.
comments.author: joebejm

comments.text: Is this for an e3dv6 hotend or a hexagon hot end? Also, have you considered making a version that would wrap around both sides and support dual fans? I think it looks just great and would have excellent airflow, and I just printed it and it came out perfect, I just have found that having the airflow from two fans has improved my prints so much, and I think this design would increase the directed airflow to directly below the hotend tip allowing for even better prints!
comments.author: corbinm

comments.text: Thanks for the print!! I hope it works well for you. I am not sure if it will fit the E3D V6 hot end or not I am using it with the standard hexagonal hot end. I have thought about about designing one with two fans but i currently do not have two 40mm fans to put into it so as soon as I get two fans to test it out I will begin designing one. Currently I have a standard 120mm pc fan duct taped to the side of my case and that seems to be doing a much better job and I am curious about if the two 40mm would be enough to equal the 120mm. Regardless I hope to have another 40mm in the next month and will begin designing a two fan version. I will upload to here when I get it finished. Thanks.
comments.author: corbinm

description.text:
Get lucky with this 4 leaf clover design. If you have seem some of my other designs you know I like to party with swizzle sticks and picks. As it turns out kids like them too - they use the ends to poke people so don't give them any of the picks. These are a great conversation starter about how fun 3d printing is. A safe, easy-to-use holder for scalpels up to 250mm long (including blade).
It will fit scalpels and hobby knives up to 4.3mm thick, but you can scale the model in Y-axis if you need it to hold thicker ones, such as with rubber-coated handles. The funnel shape guides the scalpel and makes it very easy to place. The center cutout makes it easy to pick up. Internally, the holder has a slight tilt to match common scalpel handles, which will help offload the pressure on the blade and thereby keeping it sharp longer. A simplified blade symbol clearly shows in which direction the scalpel should be - mirror the model if you are left-handed or prefer the blade to the right. The mounting holes are counterbored to completely fit the mounting screws in order to avoid contact with the scalpel blade. The model is made for standard pegboards using 12mm center hole distance; the pegboard in the photo is from Biltema. If requested, I can adapt it for other pegboard sizes.
You can also mount it directly on the wall, on a piece of wood, inside a drawer, on a really big coconut or on a wooden robot from the future, hellbent on destroying all of humanity. Have fun and stay safe! P.s. Ringing effect in photo is due to fast printing (125mm/s).

description.text: I needed some boxes to put some Arduino based (and other) projects in and wanted to play a bit more with openjscad. This is definitely just work in progress, but I thought it was kinda fun. At the heart of the project is a customisation tool written with openjscad which can be found here: http://openjscad.org/#http://www.geminidev.be/3d/arduino.jscad To use it, you should manually hide the code using the little arrow on its left (it's mostly an ugly little hack, so hiding it is a good idea :)), and turn on instant update in the parameter panel. Any models generated need to be repaired via netfabb. While I have other projects which use this, I'll start with what I call the Doodalu - which is basically just an Arduino Uno and a 2.8 Inch TFT LCD Shield Touch Display. For this, download the lid, one of the bodies, and one of the bases, slice at 0.3mm and print without support. I would suggest body should be printed first to ensure the Arduino and shield fit, followed by the lid and the base. I'll post my modified code for the doodle app at some point soon (though if you have the combination of devices available, you've probably already got one anyway) - there's an associated python script which replicates the image on your computer which is kind of interesting

title: Hold-Down Clips for Makerbot Orange Acrylic Build Sheet

description.text: Nothing original here, just standing on the shoulders of giants and copying their designs/ideas (see gator clip, horseshoe clip).  This smaller clip is for holding down the orange acrylic plate that Makerbot uses for a build surface.  The plate tends to warp a bit after several uses, and a couple of strips of double stick tape along with these clips appears to solve the problem.  Hope you find it useful.
Remember to activate the skeinforge "multiplier" for 2 by 2 before loading the stl file.  I used a raft (default settings), but then I tend to use a raft for everything.

comments.text: I love this, because i printed out almost the exact same thing early on. It works great, but on large prints doesn't the print head kick the clips off the edge of your build platform? That has been my biggest problem, anything having a raft bigger then 80x80 will start to kick off the clips.
comments.author: jrombousky

comments.text: Thanks for the response. I'm having considerable trouble with warpage on large objects, and since it appears that the solution is PLA plastic, I am staying with small stuff until PLA is available. So yes, you are correct, these clips would interfere with a large object. The last large object I tried resulted in a broken plastruder, since I tried to get a 70% spread on the beginning raft surface and the tip started dragging which stripped the threads out of the thermal block (better to lose the thermal block than the entire plastruder). Replicatorg needs a BIG estop buton and a buffer flush. It's very difficult to stop a process when bad things happen.
comments.author: jrombousky

description.text: "Cool Hotspot" is the prototype created and fabricated by team "Cyclists" during STTF2013. You can download the prototype booklet, check the code on Github, and view its final presentation video. This prototype is mainly composed by cork agglomerate and a dibond aluminun plate milled in a CNC machine, with several physical computing elements such as an Arduino, a peltier element, or a CO2 sensor, and other components as an air pump, a small air fan, or a newsletter. It was designed to fit with other similar prototypes into a central column made of recycled wood pallets and powered by a solar panel. STTF2013 is a Summer School that took place between 8-13 July 2013 at ISCTE-IUL (University Institute of Lisbon), organized by VitruviusFabLab-IUL (Digital Fabrication Laboratory) and CIES-IUL (Centre for Research and Studies in Sociology). For more information on the Summer School, its discussion, design and fabrication processes, participants, or this prototype, please visit: http://sttf2013.iscte-iul.pt

title: Fan Aspirated Weather Station Temp/Humid Solar Radiation Shields (Stevenson Screen)

description.text: This is an assembly designed to provide a fan aspirated flow of ambient air over a weather station temperature and humidity sensor assembly mounted outside on a pole or similar support. There are three different configurations provided with a separate Bill of Materials (BOM) (parts list for each. The configurations include a design that is intended to be mounted on a 1 inch OD pole (3/4" Schedule 40 PVC pipe), a bottom mounted 90 degree bracket, and a top mounted 90 degree bracket. The design uses a commonly available 40 X 40 X 20 mm 12 volt DC fan for air circulation (different voltages and airflow rating may be procured depending on the application. Many of the parts are common to all three configurations. Currently the screens are in use with a WiFi weather station from: https://wunderweatherstation.wordpress.com/

"Estou aqui (I'm here)" is the prototype created and fabricated by team "Fishermen" during STTF2013. You can download the prototype booklet, check the code on Github, and view its final presentation video. This prototype is mainly composed by cork agglomerate, with several physical computing elements such as an Arduino or LEDs, and other components as a lead fishing weight. It was designed to fit with other similar prototypes into a central column made of recycled wood pallets and powered by a solar panel. STTF2013 is a Summer School that took place between 8-13 July 2013 at ISCTE-IUL (University Institute of Lisbon), organized by VitruviusFabLab-IUL (Digital Fabrication Laboratory) and CIES-IUL (Centre for Research and Studies in Sociology). For more information on the Summer School, its discussion, design and fabrication processes, participants, or this prototype, please visit: http://sttf2013.iscte-iul.pt

description.text: For those of you that use outcastrc's P3Steel - E3d V6 bowden dual extruder mount, but want to use an 18mm inductive sensor -- I have remixed the "cap" to have a sensor loop. It's symmetrical, so you can place the sensor loop on either side of the carriage. If you would like a different size sensor hole, let me know and I will remake it. I have only supplied the "cap", for the rest of the mount please visit outcastrc's thing @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672917 EDIT: Added a second cap with a loop that's lower, hopefully helps anyone with a short sensor. Both LH and RH sensor configurations are available for download with this style of loop.

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Mine is 65mm long but the threaded portion only runs from the tip up to about 49mm, I currently use a 25mm lowering mount on a Greg's Wade extruder (although I could get away with using a 10mm lowering mount on my current setup). author: andbad

description.text: Replaces the original Y-Axis Belt Tensioner for HICTOP 3DP-11 and 3DP-12 Aluminum frame printers. The acrylic original will crack and crumble under stress and can produce slippage on the Y-Axis as your bely wears or losens. Uses original M5 bolt and tee nuts and the original bearing M8 bolt and nut. Four bolt holes are 7.6mm wide and spaced 5mm on centers apart. Screw your M8 bolt right into the hole at the tension you need. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/doCWsPXyRoL

comments.text: Update: Hi, as i type this your belt tensioner has just completed printing, it was cura v16.xx that was adding extra code so i tried the latest cura v2.xx and had no problems with the print. Strange that cura 16.xx would do that. Also this is the first print that has completed without errors in build quality, i`m a noob at 3d printing... thanks for replying so promtply. I will upload picture when i can.
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text: Glad to hear it worked out finally. Not sure why Cura 1.6 had an issue. Good luck and hang in there! This 3D printing is just the start of a long journey, things change fast and furiously sometimes.
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text: Hi, I have tried to print the thing 3 times on my hictop 3dp17. When i load the stl & convert to g-code in cura the program says tweeking at z 5mm then saves as g-code, as i said above each time i start the print everything is fine until layer 41 then the extruder stops & parks with the lcd saying waiting for user input, is this what you coded or is cura changing code. Thanks
comments.author: Ruckinhell09

comments.text: This is the first issue I have heard. I downloaded and checked the file and received no error codes. There might be an issue with Cura or maybe the file you have corrupted during download? Have you tried downloading again and then check the STL file with an online STL validator?

This is a desk-mounted base clamp for an iMac.  The parts marked Mac_Clamp_Lower are designed to go next to the base, and include a 2 degree taper to match the angle of the iMac base. The Mac_Clamp_Upper lays over the top of the lower and the base.  The clamps are designed to be used with #14 bolts, bolted from the underside of the desk through the top, and secured with wing nuts, to allow removal of the iMac when needed.

Oh NO! Cosmos and Chaos have informed me that I have released too many Happy Faces into the universe and that I must redress the balance. Hence I have created "Evil Happy Face". To make extra sure it's working, I've given him a "power radiation" base to sit in.
Let's hope it works:-) Because this is it - no more Happy Faces:-P
Files are provided for single and dual extrusion. Assembly should be fairly obvious. Only thing I will add is that if you are printing power_radiation_base.stl on a single extrusion setup, then you will need to look at your sliced model to work out where the "bands" start and pause your print and swap out the filament. 
WARNING: My dual extrusion system is in bits at the moment, so those files have not been tested. Also I uploaded the same file twice with different names. I have now uploaded the power_bands_dual_extrusion.stl correctly.
All Happy faces are the same size so they can be swapped around. Ya know, just in case you want EVIL SUNSHINE Happy Face:-)
